qas.question: What was the difference that made American cotton preferred over Indian cotton?
In the 1840s, what country could no longer adequately supply the British cotton mills?
Besides buying from the American plantations, where else in the western hemisphere did Britain buy cotton?
By what time had cotton become prominent in the American economy of the south?
What was cotton called in the 19th century?
What was the difference that made Indian cotton preferred over British cotton?
In the 1840s, what country could no longer adequately supply the Indian cotton mills?
Besides buying from the American plantations, where else in the western hemisphere did India buy cotton?
By what time had cotton become prominent in the Indian economy of the south?
What was America called in the 19th century?

context: By the 1840s, <a1_0><b6_0>India<b6_0/><a1_0/> was no longer capable of supplying the vast quantities of cotton fibers needed by mechanized British factories, while shipping bulky, low-price cotton from India to Britain was time-consuming and expensive. This, coupled with the emergence of American cotton as a superior type (due to the <a0_0><b5_0>longer, stronger fibers<b5_0/><a0_0/> of the two domesticated native American species, Gossypium hirsutum and Gossypium barbadense), encouraged British traders to purchase cotton from plantations in the United States and plantations in the <a2_0><b7_0>Caribbean<b7_0/><a2_0/>. By the <a3_0><b8_0>mid-19th century<b8_0/><a3_0/>, "<a4_0><b9_0>King Cotton<b9_0/><a4_0/>" had become the backbone of the southern American economy. In the United States, cultivating and harvesting cotton became the leading occupation of slaves.
